li.p: How can we sketch a tangent line?
How do we find an equation for the tangent line?

introduction.p: Recall that a line can be written as y = m(x- x_0) + y_0 where m is the slope of the line and (x_0, y_0) is a point on the line. Using this information and our new derivative rules, we are in a position to quickly find the equation for the line which intersects a curve at a particular point and has the same slope, which we call the tangent line . Specifically, we have the following definition.

assemblage.title: The Tangent Line
assemblage.p: Given a differentiable function f and a point (x_0,y_0) the equation for the tangent line to the function f at (x_0,y_0) is given by y=f'(x_0)(x-x_0)+y_0.

introduction.p: We will look more at tangent lines in future sections but the basic ideas appear here. Specifically, if we know data about a function at a specific point such as it's value at that point and rate of change at that point then we can estimate its value at a future point.

subsection.title: Sketching the Tangent Line
subsection.p: We may informally sketch a tangent line by estimating the rate of change at a point x = a and following a straight line.

subsection.title: Constant and Power Functions
subsection.p: So far, we know the derivative formula for two important classes of functions: constant functions and power functions. If f(x) = c is a constant function, its graph is a horizontal line with slope zero at every point. Thus, \frac{d}{dx}[c] = 0. We summarize this with the following rule.

assemblage.title: Derivatives of Constant Functions
assemblage.p: For any real number c, if f(x) = c, then f'(x) = 0.

assemblage.title: Derivatives of Power Functions - Power Rule
assemblage.p: For any nonzero real number n, if f(x) = x^n, then f'(x) = nx^{n-1}.

li.p: First rewrite as \displaystyle g(z) = \frac{1}{z^{1/2}}=z^{-1/2} then apply the power rule \displaystyle g'(z) = \frac{-1}{2}z^{-3/2}=\frac{-1}{2z^{3/2}}.
\displaystyle h(w) = w^{\frac{3}{4}} is a power function, thus \displaystyle h'(w) = \frac{3}{4} w^{(\frac{3}{4})-1}=\frac{3}{4} w^{\frac{-1}{4}}.
First rewrite as \displaystyle r(t) = t^{3/2} then apply the power rule \displaystyle r'(t) = \frac{3}{2}t^{1/2}.
\displaystyle s(q)=q^{-1} is a power function, so \displaystyle s'(q)=(-1)q^{(-1)-1}=-q^{-2}.
\displaystyle m(t) = \frac{1}{t^3} = t^{-3} is a power function, so \displaystyle \frac{dm}{dt} = -3t^{-4} = -\frac{3}{t^4}.

subsection.title: Constant Multiples and Sums of Functions
subsection.p:
Next we will learn how to compute the derivative of a function constructed as an algebraic combination of basic functions. For instance, we'd like to be able to take the derivative of a polynomial function such as
p(t) = 3t^5 - 7t^4 + t^2 - 9 , which is a sum of constant multiples of powers of t. To that end, we develop two new rules: the constant multiple rule and the sum rule.

With the constant multiple rule, we want to answer the question how is the derivative of y = kf(x) related to the derivative of y = f(x)? Recall that when we multiply a function by a constant k, we vertically stretch the graph by a factor of |k| (and reflect the graph across the horizontal line y = 0 if k \lt 0). This vertical stretch affects the slope of the graph, so the slope of the function y = kf(x) is k times as steep as the slope of y = f(x). Thus, when we multiply a function by a factor of k, we change the value of its derivative by a factor of k as well. We note that the constant multiple rule can be formally proved as a consequence of properties of limits, using the limit definition of the derivative.

assemblage.title: The Constant Multiple Rule

subsection.p: In words, this rule says that the derivative of a constant times a function is the constant times the derivative of the function.
In practice we normally multiply the constant and the power in one step, for example if f(x)=5x^4 then f'(x)=20x^3.

Next we examine a sum of two functions. If we have y = f(x) and y = g(x), we can compute a new function y = (f+g)(x) by adding the outputs of the two functions: (f+g)(x) = f(x) + g(x). Not only is the value of the new function the sum of the values of the two known functions, but the slope of the new function is the sum of the slopes of the known functions. Therefore, Like the constant multiple rule, the sum rule can be formally proved as a consequence of properties of limits, using the limit definition of the derivative.
we arrive at the following sum rule for derivatives:

assemblage.title: The Sum Rule
assemblage.p: derivativesum rule If f(x) and g(x) are differentiable functions with derivatives f'(x) and g'(x) respectively, then \frac{d}{dx}[f(x) + g(x)] = f'(x) + g'(x).

subsection.p: In words, the sum rule tells us that the derivative of a sum is the sum of the derivatives. It also tells us that a sum of two differentiable functions is also differentiable. Furthermore, because we can view the difference function y = (f-g)(x) = f(x) - g(x) as y = f(x) + (-1 \cdot g(x)), the sum rule and constant multiple rules together tell us that \frac{d}{dx}\left[f(x)-g(x)\right]=\frac{d}{dx}\left[f(x) + (-1 \cdot g(x))\right] = f'(x) - g'(x), or that the derivative of a difference is the difference of the derivatives. We can now compute derivatives of sums and differences of elementary functions.

statement.p: Using the sum rule, we find that \frac{d}{dw} (w^4+w^7) = 4w^3+7w^6. Using both the sum and constant multiple rules, if h(q) = 3q^6 - 4q^{-3}, then h'(q) = 3 (6q^5) - 4(-3q^{-4}) = 18q^5 + 12q^{-4}.

Use only the rules for constant and power functions, together with the constant multiple and sum rules, to compute the derivative of each function below with respect to the given independent variable. Note well that we do not yet know any rules for how to differentiate the product or quotient of functions. This means that you may have to first do some algebra on the functions below before you can actually use existing rules to compute the desired derivative formula. In each case, label the derivative you calculate with its name, using proper notation such as f'(x), h'(z), \displaystyle \frac{dr}{dt}, etc.
\displaystyle f(x) = x^{\frac{5}{3}} - x^4 + 20
g(x) = 14x^6 + 3x^5 - x
\displaystyle h(z) = \sqrt{z} + \frac{1}{z^4} + 50
\displaystyle s(y) = (y^2 + 1)(y^2 - 1)
\displaystyle p(a) = 3a^4 - 2a^3 + 7a^2 - a + 12
\displaystyle q(x) = \frac{x^3 - x + 2}{x}

li.p:
\displaystyle f(x) = x^{\frac{5}{3}} - x^4 + 20, so by the sum (and difference) rule,
f'(x) =\mathstrut \amp \frac{d}{dx}\left[x^{\frac{5}{3}}\right]-\frac{d}{dx}\left[x^4\right]+\frac{d}{dx}\left[20\right] =\mathstrut \amp \frac53x^{(\frac{5}{3})-1}-4x^{4-1}+0 =\mathstrut \amp \frac53x^{\frac{2}{3}}-4x^3 .

g(x) = 14x^6 + 3x^5 - x, so by the sum and constant multiple rules,
g'(x) =\mathstrut \amp 14\frac{d}{dx}\left[x^6\right]+3\frac{d}{dx}\left[x^5\right]-\frac{d}{dx}[x] =\mathstrut \amp 14(6x^5)+3(5x^4)-1 =\mathstrut \amp 84x^5+15x^4-1 .
\displaystyle q(x) = \frac{x^3 - x + 2}{x} = \frac{x^3}{x} - \frac{x}{x} + \frac{2}{x} = x^2 - 1 + 2x^{-1}. Using the power rule repeatedly, it follows that q'(x) = 2x - 2x^{-2}.

subsection.p: In the same way that we have rules to help us find derivatives, we introduce some language that is simpler and shorter. Often, rather than say take the derivative of f, we'll instead say simply differentiate f. Similarly, if the derivative exists at a point, we say f is differentiable at that point, or that f can be differentiated there.

As we work with the algebraic structure of functions, it is important to develop a big picture view of what we are doing. Here, we make several general observations based on the rules we have so far.
The derivative of any polynomial function is another polynomial function, and the degree of the derivative is one less than the degree of the original function. For instance, if p(t) = 7t^5 - 4t^3 + 8t, then p is a degree 5 polynomial and its derivative, p'(t) = 35t^4 - 12t^2 + 8, is a degree 4 polynomial.
We should not lose sight of the fact that everything we developed in Chapter 1 regarding the meaning of the derivative still holds. The derivative measures the instantaneous rate of change of the original function as well as the slope of the tangent line at any selected point on the curve.

statement.p: Each of the following questions asks you to use derivatives to answer key questions about functions. Be sure to think carefully about each question and to use proper notation in your responses.

li.p: If \displaystyle h(z)=\sqrt{z}+\frac1z, find the slope of the tangent line to the graph of y=h(z) at the point where z = 4.
Find an equation for the tangent line to the curve y=p(a), where p(a) = 3a^4 - 2a^3 + 7a^2 - a + 12, at the point where a=-1.
What is the difference between being asked to find the slope of the tangent line (asked in (a)) and the equation of the tangent line (asked in (c))?
The slope is a number and is only one piece of the equation, which contains more information.

Note that since \displaystyle h(z) = z^{\frac{1}{2}} + z^{-1}, we have \displaystyle h'(z) = \frac{1}{2}z^{-\frac{1}{2}} - z^{-2}=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{z}}-\frac{1}{z^2}. Thus, \displaystyle h'(4) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt4} - \frac{1}{4^2} = \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{16} = \frac{3}{16}. Therefore the slope of the tangent line to the graph of y=h(z) at the point where z = 4 is \frac{3}{16}.

Given p(a) = 3a^4 - 2a^3 + 7a^2 - a + 12, first observe that p(-1) = 3 + 2 + 7 + 1 + 12 = 25, so the tangent line will pass through the point (-1,25). Furthermore, since p'(a) = 12a^3 - 6a^2 + 14a - 1, we know that the slope of the tangent line is p'(-1) = -12 - 6 - 14 - 1 = -33. An equation of the tangent line is therefore y - 25 = -33(a+1). Equivalently, y=-33a-8 is an equation of this tangent line.

Finding the slope of the tangent line only requires knowing the value of the derivative at a particular input. In contrast, finding the equation of the tangent line additionally requires knowing the value of the original function at that same input. In other words, the slope is just a number, whereas the equation incorporates additional information that together with the slope is sufficient to actually graph the tangent line.

Given a differentiable function y = f(x), we can express the derivative of f in several different notations: f'(x), \displaystyle \frac{df}{dx}, \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}, and \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}[f(x)].

The limit definition of the derivative leads to patterns among certain families of functions. These patterns enable us to compute derivative formulas without resorting directly to the definition. For example, if f is a power function of the form f(x) = x^n for any real number n other than 0, then f'(x) = nx^{n-1}. This is called the rule for power functions.

If we are given a constant multiple of a function whose derivative we know, or a sum of functions whose derivatives we know, the constant multiple and sum rules make it straightforward to compute the derivative of the overall function. More formally, if f(x) and g(x) are differentiable with derivatives f'(x) and g'(x) and if a and b are constants, then
\frac{d}{dx} \left[af(x) + bg(x)\right] = af'(x) + bg'(x) .
